Award.AwardTitle: I/UCRC FRP: Collaborative Research: MDONS (Massively Distributed Online Neuroscience) for Improving Virtual Experience
Award.AbstractNarration:
The project proposes to create a distributed, multi-user social computing environment that will develop the capabilities of human Electroencephalography (EEG) to analyze users engagement with digitally based experiences. For this project, users will wear non-invasive, EEG headsets while navigating a shared virtual world. Beginning with a handful of EEG systems, the team will scale up over the course of the project to gather signals from dozens of users, providing a basis for larger scale studies. By comparing the EEG signals with each participants activities in virtual world, and with the brain activity and the activities of other users, a model of human brain activity will be developed for different types of behavior profiles and subjective states. This will allow significant improvement for the development of neural markers of human perceptual, cognitive and affective states, the parsing of EEG signals, the applicability of EEG interfaces to new types of experiences, all of which can enhance distance learning, collaborative distributed work, improved mobile computing interfaces and health care applications. The project will advance the capabilities for determining an individuals cognitive state by the creation of new computing methods utilizing comparative EEG analysis and data analysis of event states in a digital simulation. Bringing methods of large scale data analysis to articulate patterns across many users in the situated milieu of the online virtual world will create a new method to utilize EEG analysis to infer human subjective experience. The necessity of conducting this analysis in real-time, with data gathered from distributed, wireless EEG instruments will provide the impetus for utilizing accelerated hybrid multi-core techniques to bear on this domain.

The results from the project will be applicable for a variety of digital environments including computer aided learning and training, digitally mediated collaborative work environments, visualization of complex data sets, and digitally based entertainment experiences such as virtual worlds and computer games. The project will improve the functionality and outcomes of these digital media environments, better adjusting them to the cognitive states of the users. The PIs will train and employ a diverse body of participants to be involved in these activities. As part of an internship program at the Preuss School, a nationally recognized middle and high school on the campus of UCSD, UCSD faculty and staff mentor high school seniors to provide these students valuable experiences in a research laboratory. In addition, UMBC operates the very successful Meyerhoff program for minority students, primarily African-American, for which over 90% of a yearly entrance number of more than fifty go on to graduate school in science or engineering. Many of these students are computer science majors that have had the elective graduate course of Service Oriented Computing for Scientists and Engineers.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In collaboration with UCSD, we, at UMBC, developed an EEG brain signal analysis processing system for multiple human participants interacting in a shared virtual world.  UCSD developed the virtual environment and would record their brain activity non-invasively using EEG helmets to track brain data responses and reactions. The data would be transferred to UMBC for the  conduct  of EEG  brain signal analysis from the sensors in a helmet worn by the partcipants  viewing virtual world events, for both individuals and multiple participants.  EEG is the recording of electrical activities along the scalp, produced by the firing of the neurons within the brain. The unique contribution of UMBC in this proposed effort  was to address processing ensemble data from particpant EEG head sets under identical virtual digital stimuli. The UMBC contribution addresses the implementation of Independent Component Analysis (ICA) algorithm performance for removing noise and artifacts in the data such as blinking and other incidental responses generating  electronic signals.This project is in conducted in conjunction with the UCSD CHMPR PI site and our CO-I site at UMBC CHMPR.  

We utilized Graphic Processing Units (GPUs) to perform the ICA analysis on multiple EEG helmet data to study  non-invasive observations of the relationship between brain dynamics, cognition, and behavior.  Our primary goal was to separate event-related potential (ERP), an averaging technique for separating functional brain imaging and other artifacts like blinking from reconstructed signals.  In addition we will explore the near real time data mining processing aspects by converting the ICA algorithms to run on an Nvidia Kepler GPU interfaced with an IBM power 8. 

Program grant funding was used to acquire 6 Emotiv helmets, a private manufacturer of EEG halmets  and delivered 5 helmets to the UCSD PI for data collection. We developed an ICA implementation on the UMBC bluegrit computer system consisting of an IBM Intel Westmere blades connected directly to the Nvidia GPUs to remove event related artifacts. We obtained videos developed at UCSD that distinguishes epistemic states to test ICA analysis. A significant delay was created to acquire IRB approval for human subject testing. In addition, the MDONS joint project obtained IRB approval on July 16, 2015 for Dr's. Halem Yesha and Segal as well as Ms. Dashtestani, a graduate student.

As a result of acquiring EEG helmets and developing ICA analytical tools on GPU, UMBC developed research credibility in neuroscience. This research subsequently led to the establishment of a Graduate Partnership Program between the UMBC and  the NIH National Institute of Child Health and Development to combine the UMBC  non-invasive use of EEG helmets and the NICHD dual IR scanning instrument applied to the study of Autism spectrum in children.
